reviewText:
Funny things is: I installed this game a week ago from a CD I have since 2006, and now it's on Steam. Bought it anyway, more easy when I want to play it on other PCs.

Well, to the game. If you like the first 2 Roller Coaster Tycoon, you'll like this one. It's simple, it's a top-down view, you can only rotate the camera 90 degress, you know, basic Roller Coaster stuff. You create train tracks and streets as if you were creating roller coasters on RCT. There's no secret.

The soundtrack plays accordingly to the year you're playing, it's awesome. Very relaxing.

The game starts very very easy, so you can learn basics. However, when you reach harder levels, the difficulty rises significantly. Isn't easy to play against 7 CPU controlled rival companies when you have to reach a 90% performance Index.

You may have problems understanding train tracks, routes and signalling when you start, but nothing that a little search doesn't fix. Isn't something complicated, once you understand it will be easy. Also isn't not THAT important that you learn about signaling if you're not making crossed tracks.

Anyway, I have over 2000 hours on Locomotion using my old disc (I play this since 2006, on a Windows 98). It's simple, relaxing and can be really challenging on harder maps even if you KNOW how to play properly.

reviewText:
Buyers beware (this is a extremely old game and dose not properly work with windows 7, 8 or 10. All I know is when playing on Windows 7 with a Nvidia card the screen at random will go crazy. So save often and you should be fine. Everything else works as normal.)

I do recommend this game even with the issues I stated above and the more you play the longer it takes to break it seems. There's no real campaign just missions" but its still fun even if you don't play with the missions and just "free play". Its fun and despite the poor graphics it has a nice art style and has great music. There are so many vehicles to buy and use. All have different stats. Also the AI is really dumb or really smart at times. For $6 its a worthy purchase and I would buy it all the time despite its bugs.

Update seems the issue with the screen going crazy is because of the steam overlay but still save often.

I will be attempting to make a guide but I hate writing things so don't count on it XD"

reviewText:
In 1995, Chris Sawyer painstakingly coded Transport Tycoon in assembly. To those of you not familiar with software engineering, programming in assembly is like driving a car by pouring fuel into the engine and turning the wheels yourself, as opposed to Java, which is more like driving a car by letting your cat do it.

Everybody loved Transport Tycoon, mostly because nobody could afford train sets. This is still the case, which is why OpenTTD exists.

Seeing as nobody really cared about the other forms of transport in the game, himself included, Chris Sawyer made a sequel and named it Locomotion to make it abundantly clear that even if you find anything in the game that's not a train, you are strongly urged to ignore it. It's like the man is saying trust me
date: you're not really here for the lorries that stop whenever they're being overtaken - I mean
recommended: do you even know what a lorry is? Thought so. Also the ships that are even more bland and slow than in the last game? They're that way so you can have the fun of building twisting railway bridges over the ocean because I built the game on the engine of a rollercoaster game I made! The second one! You'll never guess which! Also have fun hammering that left mouse button!"\n\nTo be fair
hoursPlayed: there's still some fun to be had building twisting mountain railroads and even bridges above entire cities using the rollercoaster tycoon 2 building tools. And you have the same degree of freedom

column17: covering much of it underneath in some kind of bizarre train fetishist orwellian fantasy

column19: with you trying to convince Zeus Transport to stop being a ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• and not take your cargo.\n\nI'm afraid being religious still won't help when all your trains start breaking down every fifth tile of the way

reviewText:
ENG:

Well laid out a clone of the original corresponding OpenTTD game, although the game is older so still, I prefer the original Transport Tycoon series. This game is not much improved in such a way that it would be more functional and more stable with newer computers as opposed to OpenTTD game. The game is mostly otherwise really good and simple, which I appreciate, but, a basic element seems to be missing from what you are used to using the OpenTTD game series and it is also more difficult than the OpenTTD game.

For this reason, I can't fully recommend the game, because when OpenTTD is free and all the other far better made and implemented, including further development of the game.

50/50 recommendations. :3

reviewText:
This, like most other 'tycoon' games, is something you either like or couldn't care less about. It's an extremely simple game with simple gameplay and simple (but pleasing!) graphics. Still runs fine with no issues whatsoever, but saying that, it's not exactly a demanding game for your computer to run. It's only real issue is caused by the AI companies, which tend to make a complete mess of the landscape as they build their infrastructure.

At the bare minimum this is a great time waster. You can be blas√© and build train tracks and roads while running YouTube or music or whatever in the background. It's also surprisingly satisfying to watch a small village grow over time into a large metropolis, courtesy of your efforts.

You can, however, play its predecessor Transport Tycoon for free, with mods. This game is pretty much identical in every way to TT, but it's still worth playing if you're into these sort of games.
voteText: 6 of 7 people (86%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I loved this game back when I was younger. It was one of my very first games I ever played on the computer! When I saw it had come out on steam I couldn't wait to play it again. It's even more fun playing it now than it was when I was younger, because now I understand more of the game's mechanics. But even as a kid I was easily able to create and manage my huge transport company! This game is well worth the price in my opinion.

The outdated graphics may be an issue to some people. In my opinion the game looks very nice for its age, and doesn't bother me in the slightest. I experienced no issues running the game on my Windows 10 laptop, and it has a max resolution of 1280x768 (which for my 1366x768 laptop screen, fits nicely!)

The basics of the game are very easy to learn, and within an hour of playing you'll already have 10 or 20 different vehicles. The AI in the game can be a bit challenging to new players, so I would recommend starting out just on your own. There is even a multiplayer component built into this game (which I have yet to try out since I don't have any other friends who own this game), but I can picture having loads of fun competing with a friend to become the top transport business!

Overall this game is a must have for people who enjoyed it before. Even if you've never tried it out, I highly recommend you at least try it! (I mean, 2 hours is plenty of time to decide if you don't like the game so you can refund it or whatever). If you're not willing to pay 6 bucks for it, then I'm sure it'll go for at least a dollar or 2 during the big sales.

10/10

reviewText:
There is an expression I and my friends sometimes use about old TV shows, games or the like, 'Better in memory'. This definitely describes Locomotion. I really enjoyed Transportation Tycoon when it came out and have great memories of playing it. To a modern me, this remake looks like something from the computer stone age and the interface feels like someone invented the mouse partway through the game's development cycle and added it on as an after thought. If you have tried to go back and play Civ 1 or the original Balder's Gate you know the feeling.

The basic idea is that you create rail services between industries and / or cities. You can also add trucking and buses, but they seem to cannibalize passengers and freight from your trains rather than taking them to and from the train station. Later on you can add in airplanes. Your actions will influence cities to grow and evolve over time.

This is a game a really wanted to like, but I couldn't play for more than a couple hours. If you enjoy nostalgia or simply like a solid transport / business game and don't mind very dated graphics and a GUI from the 80s, give this game a whirl.

Rating: D

reviewText: What a horrible game. I don't know what went wrong here, but Chris Sawyer's Original Transport Tycoon was way better. Locomotion has so many utterly confusing quirks that it makes my head spin. It's completely unintuitive. The graphics are so poor that even when spinning the map around is no guarantee that what you are about to execute will succeed. Most likely you only destroy what had nothing to do with your original intentions and on top of that, you will waste a whole lot of money in the process. Buses that go around in circles and to the wrong stations, roads that seem complete, but actually aren't, accidentally wiping out housing crucial to the community, I don't want to go into chapter and verse here, but basically this game is about as much fun as reading insurance policy disclaimers. It's rubbish and best left alone. I do recommend Transport Tycoon though. That one is fun.

reviewText:
The game has a tutorial (it's atrocious) if that's what you want to call it. It doesn't explain much of anything and you have to figure out what you have to do. The first tutorial is supposed to explain to you how to setup a bus route and make money. All it tells you is if you hold the right mouse button down you can scroll around the map. And that's it, nothing else. I sat there for a while waiting, thinking okay what will it tell me next, except there wasn't anything else.

The interface is difficult to use. I couldn't figure out what as was. You would think that if you hovered your mouse over a button it would tell you what it does, but it doesn't. So you click and hope for the best.

AI pathing is horrible. Example: Built 2 buses , they initially went to their destinations and after that all they did was drive around in circles. Deleted routes (didn't help), deleted both buses, tried again, the buses went to some stops and then got stuck driving around in circles again.

I never heard of this game before, now I know why. Played the hell out of Transport Tycoon, was hoping this one would be fun, found out it's utter crap. This is just a cheap knock off of a great game.

Got it for a buck 50, still feel ripped off.

reviewText:
This game is an old favourite of mine. I first played it in 2005 I think, having a lot of fun in the process. After finding it again on Steam, I tried to use my CD, but I got errors of compatibility. So I bought it and, for 6 U$D, it¬¥s still a very addictive game.
My only complaint is that the colours reverse, sometimes automaticaly (I read it is something in the Windows system), always after minimizing the game with the Shift key (that also happened with the CD).

You can¬¥t get bored too quickly with the game, since you can make everything, modify the scenarios the way you want and also sabotage your competitors (but what¬¥s the purpose of a game without a competition to defeat).

What I would like to see are new scenarios as DLC content (free would be a nice thing), such as zones of Germany, Russia, South America, Asia and other, random scenarios, with their respective transports. I saw lots of mods for trains, aircrafts, ships, airports, train stations etc... for the CD version made by various fans of the game, so it would be a great thing if some of those fans could make new scenarios.

To sum up, it¬¥s a fun and addictive game, but lacking in the scenarios department, though you can create your own using the Scenario Creator" tool. Also lacking are several transports
date: having only a part of the maybe hundreds that could have been included (though it would make the game difficult to run and more expensive)."

reviewText:
While there's a huge nostalgia factor with this game, it's highly enjoyable once you look past some its flaws. The general interface (taken from Rollercoaster Tycoon 2) is somewhat simplistic and user friendly and the graphics are pretty sleek for 2004.

Replacing vehicles at a high point in development and expansion is however a significant pain but can be tolerated.  The tutorial levels do cover a good chunk of the gameplay but some of the mechanics aren't fully covered and can be confusing for those not entirely familiar with management games.

In conclusion, it's definitely worth a try even if its undeniably flawed in some aspects.

reviewText: I loved playing this game when I was younger. Oh the memories...\n\nThis game teaches you how to create a sucessful transportation company. The game is great despite being old and provides a variety of challenges and you can even make your own. However, I hope there could be a game like this were player companies could compete with other player companies besides computer competitors. This could also be great if player made maps/challenges could be shared with others. The game is still a great classic regardless and I suggest people give it a try.
